raw_text:
UK economy ends year with spurt
 
 The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004 after accelerating in the last quarter of the year, says the Office for National Statistics (ONS).
 
 The figure is in line with Treasury and Bank of England forecasts. The ONS says gross domestic product (GDP) rose by a strong 0.7% in the three months to 31 December, compared with 0.5% in the previous quarter. The rise came despite a further decline in production output and the worst Christmas for retailers in decades.
 
 The annual figure marked out the best year since 2000, and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003. Growth in the final three months of 2004 marked the 50th consecutive quarter of expansion. "On the basis of the latest information the UK has entered 2005 on course to continue its record period of growth," said Paul Boateng, chief secretary to the Treasury in a statement.
 
 The ONS said the services sector, which accounts for nearly three-quarters of the UK economy, grew 1.0% in the quarter. The strong services figure was welcomed by analysts, given lacklustre retail sales in December and across the Christmas holiday period. "The fact that other services components are doing so well suggests to me that we are back to trend (growth) and I am not particularly concerned about any further slowdown," said Ross Walker, UK economist at RBS Financial Markets.
 
 However, output in the production sector contracted 0.5%, the second quarterly fall in row and a state of affairs that some economists classify as a recession. However the ONS would not comment on the definition of a recession and whether the manufacturing recovery was over. But Steve Radley, chief economist at the manufacturers' organisation EEF, said: "These figures remain at odds with what is actually happening on the ground. "Whilst companies may be experiencing tougher conditions this year, 'recession' is not a word that manufacturers would currently recognise." The ONS said a sharp fall in mining and quarrying, which was driven by oil and gas extraction, was primarily responsible for the overall contraction in manufacturing production figures.
 
 Simon Rubinsohn, chief economist at Gerrard, said: "This outturn (of 0.7%) was well ahead of the market expectations and cast doubt on the scare stories doing the rounds surrounding the current state of the UK economy." And he said the GDP figures may help to "push interest rate expectations a little higher along the curve". "The suggestion from the money markets is that the next move is now more likely to be in an upward rather than a downward direction. This is consistent with our own thinking," said Mr Rubinsohn. The Bank of England's nine-strong rate-setting committee voted unanimously earlier this month to keep interest rates steady at 4.75%, minutes of the meeting showed on Wednesday.
llama3.2:1b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, accelerating in the last quarter and surpassing previous forecasts. GDP rose by 0.7% in the third quarter compared to 0.5% in the second quarter. Despite a decline in production output and retail sales, the services sector grew at a strong rate of 1.0%. The economy entered 2005 on course for record growth.
llama3.2:3b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, with a strong 0.7% growth in the last quarter of the year, matching forecasts. The services sector grew 1.0% and the production sector contracted 0.5%. The ONS said the manufacturing recovery was likely ongoing despite concerns from some economists about recession.
gemma2:2b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, exceeding forecasts. This growth was driven by a strong performance in the services sector, while production output contracted. The ONS predicts continued economic growth in 2005.  Despite declining retail sales and the ongoing contraction in manufacturing, economists believe the UK economy is on track for sustainable growth.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, ending the year with a strong rise despite declines in production and sales for retailers. The annual figure marked out the best year since 2000, indicating continued growth during the final three months of the year. While services growth was welcome, the manufacturing sector contracted 0.5% compared to the previous quarter, primarily due to declining oil prices and an increase in extraction from deep mines.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, marking its best year since 2000 and continuing a record period of growth for 50 consecutive quarters. Services sector experienced strong growth, while production fell due to a decline in mining and quarrying caused by oil and gas extraction. The Bank of England's rate-setting committee voted unanimously to keep interest rates steady at 4.75%.
qwen2.5:3b: UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, driven primarily by growth in the services sector despite a decline in production output and weak retail sales during the Christmas period. This marked the best year for the UK economy since 2000 and was consistent with Treasury and Bank of England forecasts. Growth in the final quarter came after five decades of continuous expansion. The ONS reported that GDP rose by 0.7% in Q4, up from 0.5% in the previous quarter, primarily due to strong services sector growth (1.0%). However, manufacturing output contracted by 0.5%, with mining and quarrying contributing significantly. Despite these challenges, analysts like Ross Walker viewed the robust service sector performance as evidence of underlying strength. The GDP data has raised expectations for a possible interest rate hike in the near future.
opencoder:1.5b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004 after accelerating in the last quarter of the year, says the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The figure is in line with Treasury and Bank of England forecasts. The ONS has reported a strong 0.7% increase in GDP compared to the previous quarter. This increased GDP marked the best year since 2,000 and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003. Growth in the final three months of 2004 marked the 50th consecutive quarter of expansion. The growth has been driven by the latest information on course to continue its record period of growth.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the UK economy in 2004. Let me read through it carefully and see what key points are there.

First, the UK's economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004. They mentioned that this was a spurt compared to previous years. The ONS says GDP rose strongly in the three months ending December, with a 0.7% increase from the prior quarter. That supports forecasts from the Treasury and Bank of England.

However, there were issues: production output contracted by 0.5%, which is a second-quarter decline. Some economists consider this a recession or slow growth, but others say it's part of an ongoing recovery. Retail sales had a worse Christmas period than expected, leading to fears about a tough economic outlook for the year.

The ONS emphasized that services sector growth was strong, with nearly 3-quarters contributing to the rise. Analysts are happy with that, given poor retail data. But they're cautious because not all services components performed well.

There's also mentions of mining and quarrying contracting due to oil and gas extraction. This contributed to production contraction. Simon Rubinsohn noted the 0.7% growth was ahead of market expectations, which might hint at higher interest rates in the future.

The Bank of England's rate-setting committee voted all along, with an unprecedented meeting where they kept rates steady at 4.75%. That's a big move considering previous meetings had mixed outcomes but this one went to vote.

I need to make sure I include all these points without adding extra details or explanations. Just the main summary.

Let me start by highlighting that the UK economy showed growth, even though it wasn't ideal for the year. Mention the ONS' figures on GDP and services, the contraction in production, the impact of mining, and the Bank's rate decision.
</think>

The UK economy experienced a strong growth of 3.1% in 2004, marked by an increase of 0.7% in the three months ending December compared to the previous quarter. The ONS noted that services contributed significantly to this rise, though retail sales had a colder-than-expected Christmas period, signaling concerns about economic recovery. While production output contracted by 0.5%, suggesting possibly ongoing growth, some economists view it as a recession or slow growth. Mining activity fell due to oil and gas extraction, contributing to lower production figures. The UK's growing economy was seen as the best year since 2000, with stronger services than previous years. A vote by the rate-setting committee at an unprecedented meeting in early May confirmed rates remained steady at 4.75%, despite mixed previous results.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, following a strong 0.7% in the three months to December according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The annual figure marked out the best year since 2000 and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003. The services sector grew by 1.0%, while production output fell due to oil and gas extraction, resulting in a sharp decline in manufacturing production figures. The UK economy entered 2005 on course to continue its record period of growth. Analysts expressed hope that the UK would be able to avoid further slowdowns.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The ONS reported that gross domestic product (GDP) rose by a strong 0.7% in the three months to 31 December, compared with 0.5% in the previous quarter. The rise marked out the best year since 2000 and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003. Growth in the final three months of 2004 marked the 50th consecutive quarter of expansion, with GDP increasing by a record 16.7%.
phi:2.7b: The UK economy grew by 3.1% in 2004, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This was in line with Treasury and Bank of England forecasts and marked the best year since 2003. However, output in the production sector contracted slightly due to a decline in mining and quarrying. The services sector, which accounts for nearly three-quarters of the UK economy, saw strong growth. Despite this, some economists are concerned about the manufacturing recovery. The ONS did not comment on the definition of a recession or whether the manufacturing recovery is over.
orca-mini:3b: The UK economy ended the year 2004 with a strong 3.1% growth, which is in line with Treasury and Bank of England forecasts. In the last quarter of 2004, GDP rose by 0.7%, compared with the previous quarter. Despite a decline in production output and the worst Christmas for retailers in decades, the annual figure marked out the best year since 2000 and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003. The services sector grew 1.0% in the quarter while the other services components also showed a positive trend. However, the production sector contracted 0.5%, which is the second quarterly fall in row and a state of affairs that some economists classify as a recession. While manufacturers may be experiencing tougher conditions, "recession" is not a word that manufacturers would currently recognize. The figures suggest that interest rate expectations may push a little higher along the curve.
hermes3:3b: UK economy grew by 3.1% in 2004, ending a year with 3.1% growth in last quarter; services sector grew 1.0%. However production output fell 0.5% over two quarters.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK economy grew by 3.1% in 2004, marking its best year since 2000 and continuing its record period of expansion. The services sector contributed to this growth with a 1.0% increase in the final quarter of the year. While manufacturing production contracted 0.5%, driven by a sharp fall in mining and quarrying, primarily due to oil and gas extraction, other service components showed positive trends. Despite some concerns, experts believe the UK entered 2005 on course for further growth.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK economy grew by 3.1% in 2004, the highest since 2000, with a strong 0.7% GDP rise in the last quarter despite weak retail sales and declining production output. The services sector, making up nearly three-quarters of the economy, grew 1.0%, offsetting a 0.5% contraction in production. Analysts remained optimistic about continued growth, though concerns about manufacturing persisted. The Bank of England kept interest rates steady at 4.75%, but strong GDP figures raised expectations of a potential rate increase.
stablelm2:1.6b:
The UK economy grew by 3.1% in Q4, marking the best year since 2000 and exceeding forecasts with a growth of 0.7% in the final three months of the year, according..
Key details:
- ONS says GDP rose by an estimated 3.1% in Q4
- Strongest services sector figure since 2008
- Manufacturing output contracted by 0.5%, marking second quarterly fall in row
- Mining and quarrying output significantly impacted manufacturing production figures
granite3.1-dense:2b: The UK economy experienced a 3.1% annual growth in 2004, marking its best year since 2000 and surpassing 2003's 2.2%. This expansion was driven by a robust 0.7% increase in the fourth quarter of 2004, despite declining retail sales and the worst Christmas for retailers in decades. The services sector, which contributes nearly three-quarters to the UK economy, saw a 1.0% growth during the final quarter. However, manufacturing output contracted by 0.5%, indicating potential challenges for this sector. Mining and quarrying, driven by oil and gas extraction, were primarily responsible for the overall contraction in manufacturing production. Despite these sectors' struggles, analysts remain optimistic about sustained growth due to the 50th consecutive quarter of expansion. The Bank of England maintained its interest rate at 4.75%.
reference: Simon Rubinsohn, chief economist at Gerrard, said: "This outturn (of 0.7%) was well ahead of the market expectations and cast doubt on the scare stories doing the rounds surrounding the current state of the UK economy."The ONS said the services sector, which accounts for nearly three-quarters of the UK economy, grew 1.0% in the quarter.The ONS said a sharp fall in mining and quarrying, which was driven by oil and gas extraction, was primarily responsible for the overall contraction in manufacturing production figures.And he said the GDP figures may help to "push interest rate expectations a little higher along the curve".The UK economy grew by an estimated 3.1% in 2004 after accelerating in the last quarter of the year, says the Office for National Statistics (ONS).The annual figure marked out the best year since 2000, and was also well ahead of the 2.2% recorded in 2003."The fact that other services components are doing so well suggests to me that we are back to trend (growth) and I am not particularly concerned about any further slowdown," said Ross Walker, UK economist at RBS Financial Markets.But Steve Radley, chief economist at the manufacturers' organisation EEF, said: "These figures remain at odds with what is actually happening on the ground.
